sense.name: fire-starting tool
sense.commentary: A small piece of wood that is used to start fires. Usually refers to a device with a combustible head, but other objects can be called "matches" if they're used to start fires.
sense.examples: I always carry a book of matches with me. If you dropped a match into this gasoline tank, the whole thing will explode!

sense.name: contest
sense.commentary: MATCH[+event] A formal contest in which several people or groups compete with one another. Usually sports-related.
sense.examples: John won the match with an uppercut to the jaw. The match lasted six hours but ended in a draw. Her harsh words triggered a fierce shouting match between us.

sense.name: thing that connects
sense.commentary: Something that matches with something else, usually because of similarity or harmony between them. Can be an exact duplicate. Includes romantic pairings.
sense.examples: I need something that would be a good match for this jacket. When a match is found, an entry is made in the notebook. John had been trying to find a match for years, but with no success. I think she'll be a great match for you!

sense.name: a connection
sense.commentary: The connection between two things that match. Does not refer to any specific item in the connection. Includes romantic pairings.
sense.examples: Some think that the match between animals and their environment is too perfect to arise by evolution alone. Cupid is the mythical match maker. Our marriage was a match made in heaven.

sense.name: all connected items
sense.commentary: A collective term for all the items that are connected to one another. Includes romantic pairings.
sense.examples: John and I have been a happy match for the past ten years.

sense.name: score needed to win
sense.commentary: A sports term, for the score needed to win a contest. Most often used in formal expressions, particularly in tennis.
sense.examples: John will be going for the match point on this next volley.

sense.name: worthy opponent
sense.commentary: Refers to someone of equal ability. A peer.
sense.examples: When we're playing at our best, we're a match for anybody. You've met your match, Mr. Kasparov.
